I. INTRODUCTION
1. The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support Pacific developing
member countries (DMCs) to strengthen energy reforms through the Office of Pacific Energy
Regulators  Alliance  (OPERA)1 by  undertaking  national  and  regional  capacity  building  and
generating and sharing knowledge. The TA will enable Asian Development Bank (ADB) to meet
emerging requests for analytical support from Pacific DMCs in undertaking annual review of
energy regulation and tariffs. The TA will focus on strengthening the regulation of power utilities
to promote clean energy technologies that will help decarbonize Pacific economies and achieve
nationally determined contribution (NDC) targets.2 It will assist in the preparation of regulation
reforms that embed market-based incentives for attracting private participation in the energy
sector. The TA will also raise the awareness of emerging regional issues and challenges in
attracting private investment in the energy sector, including the use of public–private partnership
(PPP) transparency frameworks to develop a more efficient and transparently regulated power
sector.
2. This TA aligns with ADB Strategy 2030 priorities, particularly in its emphasis on major
global commitments, such as the Sustainable Development Goals and the Paris Agreement on
climate change. It emphasizes ADB’s role as (i) a regional knowledge provider focused on
providing practical solutions that fit local conditions, identifying lessons, and replicating good
practices across the Pacific and beyond; and (ii) a convener of energy sector stakeholders (e.g.,
regulators, private sector, and development partners) to promote dialogue and collaboration.
Enhanced regulation will contribute to achieving ADB Strategy 2030’s goal of supporting small
island  developing  states  in  improving  the  business  environment,  reforming  state-owned
enterprises, enhancing PPPs to reduce the cost of doing business, strengthening the quality of
public service delivery, and promoting private sector-led growth.3 The TA is closely aligned with
ADB’s operational priorities of fostering regional cooperation and integration (operational priority
[OP]  7);  accelerating  progress  in  gender  equality  (OP1);  strengthening  governance  and
institutional capacity (OP4); and tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience,
and enhancing environmental sustainability (OP3). The TA is included in the Pacific Regional
Operations  Business  Plan  2021-2023  and  is  aligned  with  the  Pacific  Renewable  Energy
Investment Facility.4
II. ISSUES
3. Renewable energy has the potential to transform the Pacific energy market. The global
deployment of renewable energy in recent years has been increasing very rapidly, mostly due to
new technologies and a drastic decline in investment costs. In addition to highly competitive
renewable energy generation, battery energy storage technologies are becoming more available
and affordable as a solution to balancing the intermittency of solar and wind power and to
improving network reliability and stability.5 The potential of solar rooftop photovoltaic, microgrids,
and decentralized energy supply calls for new business models and policy and regulatory reforms
1  DMCs which will be supported are OPERA founding members (Samoa, Tonga, Vanuatu),
Pacific Island countries which also joined the alliance (Cook Islands, Fiji, Palau, Papua New Guinea ,
Solomon Islands), and other Pacific DMCs (Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia,
Nauru, Niue, Tuvalu).
2  Regional Pacific NDC Hub. 2021. Strategy 2030 A Blueprint for NDC Implementation in Pacific Island Countries. 
Suva. 
3  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
4  ADB. 2020. Pacific Regional Operations Business Plan, 2021–2023. Manila.  
5  International Renewable Energy Agency. 2021. Tracking SDG7. The Energy Progress Report. Washington, DC.

2 
in Pacific DMCs.6 The private sector has significant potential in the Pacific to bring innovation and 
scale up investment, while the public sector seeks to improve the regulatory environment for 
private  sector  participation  and  use  market-based  incentives.  As  such,  there  are  many 
opportunities for Pacific DMCs to move away from traditional state utility-dominated models by 
developing PPPs to achieve sustainable and cleaner energy. Experiences in other ADB DMCs 
show that progressive regulation and tariff reforms can be pivotal in attracting private investment 
in renewable energy and to compete with other generation sources.7 
4. Limited private sector participation in energy. Pacific DMCs are committed to a shared
vision for the region’s energy sector and the development of an enabling environment for private
sector participation, with access to disaster resilient, affordable, and financially sustainable energy.
8 However, Pacific DMCs have been slow in adopting renewable energy technologies because of
both supply and demand constraints. On the supply side, private investors are not attracted to the
Pacific DMCs as markets in the countries are small and difficult to access, and, in many cases,
private-sector developers are not familiar with the risks faced by the small island developing states
in the subregion.9 On the demand side, government energy sector policies and regulations are
largely not well structured, transparent, nor private sector friendly, as institutions lack the capacity
to reform regulation and tariffs.10 In most instances, electricity services are provided by state-
owned, vertically-integrated natural monopolies, with regulatory decisions driven by political
imperatives on an ad hoc and unpredictable basis. Regulatory and sector governance regimes of
this nature, especially in capital-constrained environments that typify the Pacific, do not provide
for efficient management of scarce resources, nor deliver satisfactory sector development and
outcomes. Where countries have stated their desire to attract private investment into the energy
sector to supplement or supplant scarce public resources, a robust and predictable regulatory
regime becomes crucially important.
5. Constrained regulatory capacity. Pacific DMCs have recognized the importance of
regulation and many of them have established dedicated national regulatory bodies to perform
regulatory functions. Other DMCs operate the regulatory framework through smaller units spread
throughout  several  agencies  or  ministries,  resulting  in  less  efficient  and  effective  reforms.
However, the capacity of all national regulatory authorities has been slow to develop, in part
attributable to the small scale of each country’s sector and low level of investment in capacity
building, as well as limited and disparate understanding of modern regulatory concepts among
policymakers  and  regulatory  professionals.  These  constraints  to  development  of  regulatory
capacity have been recognized by some regulatory practitioners in the region, and attempts have
been made to address them through professional exchanges and pooling of resources to benefit
from economies of scale.11
6. Nascent regional regulatory collaboration. Founded in 2016 by the heads of energy
regulatory bodies of Samoa, Tonga, Vanuatu, and Secretariat of the Pacific Community (SPC), 
OPERA has been mandated to (i) support harmonization of the regulation regimes of OPERA

3 
members; (ii) facilitate training and capacity-building opportunities for Pacific regulators; and 
(iii) promote affiliation with, and membership in, other regional and international regulatory
organizations. While a constitution for OPERA was adopted by its founding members, OPERA
has not been established as a legal entity in any jurisdiction and exists solely as a network of
energy regulators in the Pacific DMCs. Hosted by SPC, OPERA is led by a chairman elected by
OPERA members and supported by SPC staff. With ADB TA support, OPERA has developed its
first business plan and key priority actions for 2021–2023, approved by all members.12 To
enhance OPERA’s policy dialogue and capacity building for Pacific energy regulators (including
non-OPERA members), ADB TA supported (i) the first workshop on power purchase agreements’
transparency and disclosure standards, and (ii) the preparation and approval of power purchase
agreements’ transparency guidelines.13
7. The  objective  of  the  proposed  TA  is  to  promote  regional  cooperation  in  creating
progressive regulation of energy utilities in the Pacific by strengthening and enabling OPERA to
deliver capacity-building interventions, lead the generation and exchange of knowledge and skills,
and leverage Pacific DMCs’ limited resources to address common sector development issues
and challenges. The TA will support OPERA’s network, by strengthening its administrative and
governance  structures,  sustainability,  and  mechanisms  for  fund  raising  and  management,
including attracting support from other development partners and OPERA members.
III. THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
A. Impact and Outcome
8. The TA is aligned with the following impacts: sustainable, low-carbon and climate-resilient
Pacific created; and national and regional policy and regulatory frameworks and business-
enabling environment improved.14 The TA will have the following outcome: regional collaboration
and regulation framework for development of Pacific energy sector strengthened.15
B. Outputs, Methods, and Activities
9. Output 1: Sustainability of OPERA strengthened. The TA will support the development
of OPERA’s governance framework and improvement of its policies and procedures to empower
OPERA as a regional regulation advisory entity in the Pacific subregion. The TA will strengthen
OPERA’s governance and functional structures, and annual work planning, budgeting, and
funding procedures and processes. This will help OPERA to undertake regional regulatory
capacity  building  and  cooperation.  The  TA  will  also  support  the  preparation  of  OPERA’s
communication strategy and action plan to enhance its regional profile and knowledge sharing
practices.  The  TA  will  assist  OPERA  in  creating  a  sustainable  knowledge-sharing  and
management partnership with a similar regional or global regulation association.
10. Output 2: Regional capacity building, knowledge sharing, and policy dialogue
organized. The TA output will create a virtual experts’ hub to respond to requests from Pacific
DMCs for regulation reform advice in support of investment programs, including those with private
12 ADB. 2019. Small-Scale Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance for the Development of the Pacific Energy 
Regulators Alliance. Manila. 
13 This is the first in its kind initiative piloted regionally among ADB DMCs and supported by the National Association 
of Regulatory Utility Commissioners and Energy for Growth Hub (https://www.energyforgrowth.org/).  
14 Regional Pacific NDC Hub. 2019. Pacific NDC Hub Strategy 2030. Suva.; Pacific Community. 2021. Framework for
Energy Security and Resilience in the Pacific 2021–2030. Noumea. 
15 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
sector participation. Advisory outputs will include regulation and tariff studies and gender-inclusive 
policy recommendations that enable decarbonization and leapfrogging of traditional models 
through, for example, PPPs. ADB will review all government requests under this output and 
provide support linked to ongoing or ensuing investments and programs while ensuring strong 
coordination and harmonized approaches with key development partners’ ongoing and planned 
assistance. The TA will help OPERA create a regional information clearinghouse with a complete 
set of gender-inclusive regulation templates and tariff models for the use of Pacific regulation 
authorities. This output will be delivered through regional capacity building, knowledge sharing, 
and training activities that will be conducted with at least 30% participation by women. It will help 
increase awareness of international experience and expertise to better inform Pacific regulation 
authorities and increase links among key energy sector actors.  
11. Output 3: Analytical studies on priority regional development issues in utilities
regulation  and  tariffs  developed.  Output  3  will  support  necessary  policy  and  regulatory
improvements, increased private sector participation, and informed investment decisions by
undertaking analytical studies on priority development issues in regulation and tariffs. A Pacific 
regulation and tariff benchmark study will be prepared together with at least three regional studies 
on comparative regulation and tariff reforms. The TA will support dissemination of these regional 
analytical studies and lesson-sharing among related regulation authorities in Pacific DMCs – this 
will further strengthen OPERA’s capacity and institutional role (output 1) and its function in 
capacity building and training for Pacific regulation authorities (output 2).
C.  Cost and Financing
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which (i) $250,000 will be financed on a grant
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other  sources);  and (ii) $350,000 
will be  financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.  16 
The  key  expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The Secretariat of the Pacific Community 
(SPC) will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, offic e, office supplies, 
and other in-kind contributions.
D.  Implementation Arrangements
13. ADB is the executing agency and will administer the TA through the Pacific Department’s
Energy Division (PAEN). PAEN will engage, select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize
workshops; and provide staff to act as resource persons in the workshop in close coordination
with SPC that performs administration support to OPERA. PAEN will coordinate closely with the
Energy  Sector  Group  Secretariat  in  the  Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change
Department for Output 2 and Output 3.
14. Consulting services. ADB will engage individual consultants (international, national and
regional), including resource persons, following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.
Engagement of individual consultants (i) allows for the mobilization of experts with policy reform
and regulation expertise and (ii) provides greater flexibility in project implementation, which
mitigates the risks and constraints caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The consultants will work
closely with SPC and OPERA.

IV. THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION
16. The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for
Development of the Pacific Energy Regulators Alliance, and hereby reports this action to the
Board.
